Past experience has shown that the sum of two dol - lars, per week is not sufficient to pay for the care of such children ; that the board and lodging of the children has cost the state a minimum of three dollars per week; and that clothing, medical attention and other attention and other expenses have been furnished at an additional cost to the state. We recommend that this provision of the statute be amended so that in the case of children who are received and cared for temporarily, their legal guardians or the counties of their residence be required to pay a sum to be fixed by this Board in an amount equal, as nearly as may be, to the actual per capita cost of maintaining these chil - dren. In the revised statutes of 1913 there is some ambiguity as to the name which should be applied to this department. We recommend that the statute be amended and that the organization be designated "The Nebraska Home for De - pendent Children." NEBRASKA REFORMATORY The small prison population of the state, with its mil - lion and a quarter inhabitants, as compared with the prison population of other states is a matter of congratulation and

■40 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF mutual felicitation. The improved conditions now prevail - ing at the Nebraska prison and a wise and judicious exer - cise of the provisions of the parole law have kept the popu - lation of this institution reduced to the minimum, and have afforded opportunities for the release of those who have been confined there for brief periods of time and who have proven themselves worthy and entitled to consideration and clemency. The last legislature in its wisdom provided for further reform and improvement in the administration of the penal laws of the state by the establishment of a reformatory for first-offenders, it being provided in the act that such an institution should be established and open to all male per - sons between the ages of 16 and 30, who for the first time had been convicted of a felony and, by the trial judge, sen - tenced to confinement at such institution. An appropria - tion in the sum of $150,000.00 was made by the legisla - ture for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of the act. The general demands made upon us at the time we began the discharge of our duties in the organiza - tion and government of all the institutions coming under our control, and especially in an effort to aid in the further improvement of the affairs connected with the manage - ment of the state prison, which had theretofore been begun by you as Governor aided and assisted by the present War - den, it being our especial desire to facilitate the work thus begun in every way possible, suggested to us the wisdom of deferring action with respect to the establishment of a reformatory until a later period, and for reasons of this character, nothing was done by us during the remainder of the year 1913, in this connection save to obtain all pos - sible information we were able to in order to be fully ad - vised and informed as to all matters pertaining to the es - tablishment, future work, and usefulness of such an in - stitution. Early in the year now drawing to a close we began a systematic effort looking to the carrying out of the pro - visions of the legislature and as a part of the general scope of this particular work thus engaged in, and having our attention called thereto by different localities, a majority

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 41 of the members of the Board visited a large number of localities with the view of examining the local situation and informing themselves fully as to the advisability, avail - ability and respective merits of the different places thus visited and proposed sites examined as a suitable location for such an institution. The Board visited some sixteen different parts of the State, making at each an examina - tion of one or more places with especial reference to the advantages offered and the desirability and wisdom of lo - cating the proposed reformatory at such place. These visits and examinations were made from time to time as opportunity therefor presented itself, and covering a per - iod of some eight or ten months. Much valuable informa - tion regarding the subject was thus obtained, and the Board now feels quite familiar with the local situation and differing conditions existing in many parts of the State with respect to the establishment of such an institution. Much valuable data was collected during these visits and much information and many suggestions regarding the subject generally were obtained from many other sources. The Board has kept in view at all times the main pur - poses and objects of an institution of this kind as expressed by the legislature ( and has regarded and now regards out - of-door work and especially the pursuit of agriculture in all its varied branches as being best suited for offering healthy, wholesome, and useful employment to those who might become inmates of this institution, and of affording opportunities for reformation, training and improvement in character and for their return to society better fitted to engage in useful employment and to become law-abiding, self-supporting citizens. We have also been greatly impressed with the advan - tage of having in connection with land for agricultural purposes, facilities for obtaining the raw material used in the manufacture of certain kinds of building material, especially that of brick and its related products. The legislature intended and we have felt the wisdom and advisability of obtaining, as a site for this proposed reformatory at least 640 acres of land to be used princi - pally for agricultural purposes, and also, if possible, some

FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF 42 clay or shale bearing land, suitable for brick making, etc. The purchase of the required amount of land will necessi - tate the expenditure of $80,000.00 to $90,000.00 of the appropriation made. Possibly $100,000.00 will be required in order to obtain the best site which may be found avail - able for this purpose. It is our judgment that upon the acquisition of the re - quired amount of land and the fixing of the exact location for the reformatory, the development of the institution should be very carefully entered upon, beginning in a small way and gradually increasing the capacity until we have reached the probable maximum demand for the caring of those who will become inmates therein ; also that much of the work in the way of building, improving the real estate, and developing the institution should be done by the in - mates sentenced to confinement therein ; that only where skilled help is required which the State does not have at its command, and only when material is required that the State cannot manufacture itself, should there be expense and outlay in the way of both labor and material. It oc - curs to us that the buildings first constructed should be such as to serve a permanent, useful purpose but in the first instance to provide for the immediate wants of the institution in the way of housing inmates, officers, and employes, and sheltering live stock; that gradually, there - after, other and more permanent buildings especially adapted for a particular purpose should be constructed, the first ones erected being put to other uses as rapidly as those of a permanent character are completed, and it is to be borne in mind, however, that from the very incep - tion of the work, the future demands should be always kept in view and the buildings and improvements construc - ted in such a way that later on by extensions and addi - tions, enlargements may be made in conformity with a pre-arranged plan and outline, and thus in time develop the institution into a complete well-arranged and sym - metrical group of buildings and improvements, which 3hall met the lasting needs and demands of the institution. By a gradual process of development of this charcter, it is believed that accommodations may be provided for all those

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 43 who will probably become inmates therein from time to time, they be given useful work, and the growth and de - velopment of the institution will keep pace with the in - creased demand in harmony with the growth of the state. After the expenditure of the amount required for the necessary land upon which the institution is to be located, it is believed that the remainder of the appropriation will provide for the necessary buildings to be constructed dur - ing the present biennium, and that the construction during the present biennium, and that the construction of such buildings will provide for the housing and employment of those who will be placed therein during the remainder of this period and that by the development of the institution gradually as above outlined, more in the way of economy can be accomplished than otherwise. It will be essential, of course, upon the establishment of the reformatory to have provisions made for the officers and employees necessary to man the institution; for their support and maintenance as well as that of the inmates, and for the purchasing of machinery for the manufacture of brick, if we are to engage in such work ; for the pur - chase of live stock and the equipment of the farm with farm machinery ; all of which, in our judgment, will re - quire the expenditure during the coming biennium of at least $50,000.00 in addition to the sum already appropri - ated. In brief, the above is an outline of what has been done and what, in our judgment, should be done in the fu - ture in the location, establishment and development of a reformatory such as is contemplated by the statute. If our views are concurred in by you as Governor and by the legislature, we respectfully suggest and recommend the wisdom of re-appropriating, so that the same may be available during the entire coming biennial period, the $150,000.00 heretofore appropriated, it being provided that none of the old appropriations should be used, and the further sum of $50,000.00 for the purpose last above men - tioned.

44 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF OFFICIAL VISITS TO INSTITUTIONS We append to and present herewith a tabulated state - ment of visits to the different institutions of the entire membership of the Board and also by the different mem - bers thereof from time to time. It is proper, perhaps, in this connection to call attention to the fact that in the aggregate these several visits have consumed a great deal of the time of the members of the Board as a part of the general work in which it is engaged. It is our conviction, however, that the information gained by these personal visits fully justifies the time and expense required there - for.

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS ■Jit ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURES REQUIRED DURING THE COMING BIENNIAL PERIOD We present herewith a statement showing the needs and requirements of the different institutions in the way of ap - propriations to meet necessary expenditures during the bi - ennium beginning April 1st, 1915, and ending March 31st, 1917. In the estimate presented we have grouped or classified the expenses to be met and provided for into what we have denominated "Ordinary Expenses" and "Extraordinary Ex - penses," the latter including disbursements for the construc - tion of new buildings or permanent additions to present ones together with other permanent and lasting improvements and the purchase of land, the items of which are specifically stated. In the class denominated "Ordinary Expenses" is included all other expenses connected with the management, control, maintenance and support of these several institu - tions. It is deemed advisable by us to keep separate the ex - penditures made for permanent and lasting improvements, new structures, the purchase of land, etc., from the gen - eral disbursements made from day to day of current ex - penses and which in the main are common to all institu - tions. As a part of the estimates of ordinary expenditures we present an analysis or detailed statement of the different items and purposes of expenditures going to make up the sum total of all the ordinary expenditures of each institu - tion. While these detailed statements determine approxi - mately the different amounts required for the different purposes mentioned they cannot in the nature of things be made certain and accurate for the reason that it is im - possible to determine in advance with perfect certainty the amount required as to each specific item to meet the needs of the institutions for a future period covering two years. Circumstances unforseen and which cannot be taken into account many times enter into the question of future ex - penditures which time alone can determine. It is for rea - sons of this nature that we have grouped the expenditures

50 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF in total sums with the view of enabling us in directing and providing for future expenditures and the actual neces - sities of the institutions to have a degree of elasticity whereby if a saving can be effected with respect to one item and extraordinary demands arise which require a greater expenditure than anticipated as to another item; then, the loss in one will equal the gain in the other so that in the end we will be enabled to meet all proper demands without incurring deficiencies as to some particular item to be met and provided for by future legislation. It may also be suggested that were all of the sums or totals esti - mated as the required expenditures of the several different institutions merged into a grand total for all institutions, to be used wherever occasion arises to meet the reason - able and necessary requirements as to the expenditures of each institution, this would give us greater opportunities for meeting extraordinary demands in one instance by our ability to curtail in others and thus with more certainty meet the requirements and actual necessities for the entire biennial period out of the aggregate amount thus provided for. In concluding our statement regarding legislative ap - propriations for future needs of the institutions under the control of the Board, we beg to respectfully state and sug - gest with earnestness and sincerity that in arriving at the amounts required to meet the wants and needs of the in - stitutions we have in all instances most carefully and thor - oughly considered every factor entering into the question in order to reach correct conclusions ; and we have fixed the different amounts estimated and requested as neces - sary at the lowest sums which seem to us consistent with the proper conduct of the work and the carrying out the ob - jects and purposes of the institution. It is to be hoped that our recommendations regarding these matters are under - stood as being presented not with the view of having the im - pression arise or prevail that the amounts determined upon are given with the view of having them reduced under the belief, as is too frequently the case, that requests are made for appropriations in excess of the actual needs for which requested with the view that they will be cut down to some

THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 51 extent in any event. In the biennial report of the super - intendents of the different institutions are estimates made by them of needed appropriations which far exceed in amount the sums asked for by us. Our conclusions have been reached after a survey of the entire field and a care - ful study and revision of the estimates as thus made by the different superintendents. In this connection we de - sire to say that in our judgment the superintendents in making these requests have acted with sincerity, consider - ation and discrimination and from their viewpoint feel an actual necessity for the appropriation of the sums re - quested. It is to be said also that it may be very true that much larger sums than have been requested by this Board could be used wisely and judiciously and would be of ma - terial benefit in carrying on and advancing the work in this branch of the state's business. We, however, have felt that appropriations may be swollen to the point of being burdensome to the tax-payer and it is preferable to ask for the lowest sum which seems reasonably consistent with the proper discharge of the work and to keep buildings and improvements in suitable condition and repair, and enlargement of capacity gradually rather than to under - take too much during any one biennium. A reduction of the amounts asked for would, we fear, seriously hinder, if not actually cripple the usefulness of these different insti - tutions. THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 57 Extraordinary Expenses: New building and furnishings for home for dependent children, officers and employees % 27,500 Grand total $ 62,520.00 $2,087,720.00 Total estimated ordinary expenses Total estimated extraordinary expenses 359,000.00 Total estimated ordinary and extraordinary expenses $2,446,720.00 BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS OF STATE INSTITUTIONS Salaries of three commissioners and secretary $ 21,600.00 Employees' wages, office furniture, fixtures, equipment. supplies, books, blanks, printing, stationery, postage, traveling expenses and all other expenses 18,000.00 Total $ 39,600.00 FINANCIAL REPORT We transmit herewith a complete and detailed state - ment of all financial transactions, receipts and expendi - tures including appropriations made by the legislature and expenditures therefrom together with all receipts and dis - bursements from funds derived by the different institu - tions from other sources and in which is shown the bal - ance remaining unexpended at the end of the period cov - ered by this report. The statement includes all of the dif - ferent funds over which we have had control. This report shows in detail the appropriations made by the last legislature and expenditures preceding the time this Board began its work and the expenditures made by it since and until November 30th, 1914, the end of the bi - ennial period, together with the balance of the ap - propriations remaining unexpended December 1st, 1914. Calling attention to the recapitulation of the appro - priations and expenditures made therefrom it is proper to note that of the total appropriation for the biennial period of $2,894,134.38 there was a balance remaining unexpend - ed on December 1st of $900,257.22, or, including the bal - ances in the appropriation made to this Board and for the

58 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF benefit of the Advisory Board, the total balance un - expended of $905,771.31. It should be noted, however, in this connection that there was appropriated for a reforma - tory $150,000.00 and for a binding twine factory $35,000.00 or a total of $185,000.00 in these two items, none of which has been expended. The expenditures as shown by this statement cover a period of nineteen months of the twenty - four, leaving five months yet to be provided for. We de - sire also to call attention to the distribution statement of expenditures in which disbursements have been divided into numerous classifications and the amount expended by each institution under each classification thereon shown, together with the total expenditures for each of the different classifications shown ; and the total expendi - tures of each of the different institutions as to all of the classifications thus shown. Also attention is called to the recapitulation sheet covering a period of one year from December 1st, 1913, to December 1st, 1914, showing by months the number of employees, the number of inmates, the total population and the total cost of maintenance including and excluding salaries, together with the per capita cost thereof, with explanatory notes. These different financial statements together with the oth - ers more in detail accompanying this report disclose the actual transactions and facts with regard to all expendi - tures and it is believed that they will be quite helpful in determining the actual wants and needs and the necessary reasonable expenditures that are required in order to properly carry on the future work in these several institu - tions. We have given the matter much study with the ob - ject of ascertaining wherever we can where expenses may be reduced without in any wise militating against the effic - ient control and management of the institution under consid - eration. They are helpful in a comparative way in that the different expenditures for the same purpose in the different institutions may be examined and compared, bearing in mind always, however, that the population, the amount re - quired for salaries and wages and local conditions and en - vironment have a very material bearing upon the pro - priety and reasonableness of the expenditures thus made.

THE, BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 81 DISTRIBUTION STATEMENT OF EXPENDITURES For the Board of Commissioners of State Institutions for the seventeen months' period, July 1, 1913, to Decem- ber 1, 1914. AMOUNT CLASSIFICATION EXPENDED Salaries and wages of commissioners and employees $19,760.23 Salaries of extra help in office of board 566.25 Salaries of extra help outside of office of board 427.32 Professional or expert services 10.00 Premiums on bonds of commissioners 135.00 Postage 725.14 Telephone and telegraph 238.00 Railroad fare _. 590.53 Traveling expense, outside of railroad fare 109.40 Advertising 115.98 Printing, stationery and office supplies 2,503.07 Towel service 14.00 Furniture and equipment 1,448.78 Electrical supplies 115.28 Painting office rooms 124.73 Painting signs on doors 6.00 Hardware (hammer and saw) 2.25 Notary's commission and bond 8.00 Total $26,899.96

82 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT OF STATISTICAL STATEMENT Showing number of officers ; number of inmates ; total population ; actual cost of maintenance, less salaries and wages ; salaries and wages ; total actual cost of maintenance including salaries and wages ; all other expenditures ; and grand total expended for each month beginning December 1, 1913, and ending November 30, 1914. Monthly average of the foregoing for year December 1, 1913— December 1, 1914. Monthly per capita cost based on inmates for year De - cember 1, 1913 — December 1, 1914. Monthly per capita cost based on total population for year December 1, 1913 — December 1, 1914. Note — (a) Actual maintenance cost excludes all items paid from general repairs, permanent improvements, new buildings and similar appropriations, (b) Average month - ly population of the month preceding the month named is used throughout on account of the fact that payments, in the main, are made for items of indebtedness incurred by and under the population of the month preceding that in which payments are, in fact, made.

100 FIRST BIENNIAL REPORT In conclusion we call attention to the several reports of the superintendents of each of the different institutions under our control, which are presented herewith and which in many instances contain much of value in the way of in - formation and suggestions and also much of a statistical nature and which in detail show the work that has been accomplished during the two-year period covered by the reports. We respectfully submit the above for such consider - ation and action as may be deemed worthy and wise. In concluding this, our report in general, we wish to express our appreciation for the many courtesies and acts of kindness and helpful suggestion in the performance of our work received from you, as Governor, and from other state officers with whom we have been associated. We especially appreciate the hearty co-operation and earnest work which has been done by superintendents and other officers and employees in our efforts to reach the highest possible degree of success. BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS OF STATE INSTITUTIONS, Silas A. Holcomb, Chairman, Howard Kennedy Henry Gerdes. Lincoln, Nebraska, November 30, 191 Jt.
